Award.AwardTitle: Dissecting Catalytic Features of Diverse Methionyl-tRNA Synthetase Enzymes

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Protein synthesis is one of the most critical cellular activities of any organism. Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases are essential enzymes in protein biosynthesis, catalyzing the attachment of amino acids to tRNA adaptors for ribosomal decoding of genetic information. Many tRNA synthetases have additional roles in cellular regulation separate from their function in translation. This project investigates mechanistic features of methionyl-tRNA synthetase, which is a distinctive tRNA synthetase in that its tRNA isoacceptors have divergent fates in translational initiation versus elongation. The tRNA synthetases exist in both monomeric and dimeric forms in different organisms, and, in some organisms, they contain appended protein domains that expand their cellular functions. Using tools of molecular biology, computational chemistry, and mechanistic enzymology, this research seeks to expand understanding of evolutionarily distinct methionyl-tRNA synthetase enzymes in protein biosynthesis and novel cellular activities.

Broader Impacts. The project provides training in modern biological chemistry techniques to emerging scientists at Wake Forest University, a liberal arts university. The local community is impacted through after-school science clubs offering hands-on enrichment activities for at-risk middle school students. These science clubs are led by undergraduate students in a seminar course on the history of women in science, thus providing a real-world example of the challenges inherent in increasing participation of populations typically underrepresented in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Protein biosynthesis is a critical event in the life of an organism, connecting the genetic information stored in the form of DNA (or RNA for some viruses) with the proteins that make up the functional components of a cell. This translation of information from the nucleic acid language to that of proteins (made of amino acids) must be both rapid and accurate. A key component of translational accuracy is the family of enzymes called aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases. Our lab studies one member of this family, namely the protein methionyl-tRNA synthetase (MetRS). MetRS is required for incorporation of methionine into proteins; methionine is the first amino acid in most proteins and is also present within the body of proteins. With funding from NSF, we have studied how MetRS recognizes (binds) its partner tRNA and communicates that binding event through the protein and tRNA to efficiently catalyze formation of the methionylated tRNA necessary for accurate translation of the genetic message. We have used computational approaches and mutagenesis experiments to evaluate the role that macromolecular flexibility plays in enzyme catalysis. We determined that changes to tRNA flexibility that seem significant computationally can be compensated for when the tRNA is bound by the MetRS enzyme. That is, the enzyme induces a catalytically active conformation even when there are mutations to the tRNA sequence. We have also made mutations to the enzyme and studied these both computationally and experimentally; depending on the location of the mutation, these are more detrimental to enzyme activity than are mutations to the tRNA. This work will result in four publications.

We have also been studying an unusual bacterial MetRS enzyme that contains a large extra protein module attached to the canonical domain responsible for tRNA methionylation. In the bacterial Mycoplasma penetrans, the N-terminal protein domain has sequence similarity to aminotransferase enzymes. Indeed we have determined that the M. penetrans N-terminal domain is able to synthesize methionine from an amino group donor (for example an amino acid) and 2-keto-4-(methylthio)butyrate (the alpha keto precursor of methionine). Not only does the aminotransferase domain catalyze methionine formation, but the synthetase domain is able to use methionine for aminoacyl-tRNA production. This finding is quite surprising and seems to be the only example of such an activity coupled to a MetRS enzyme. This work will result in two publications.

Three PhD students, one postdoctoral fellow, and numerous (>10) undergraduates have participated in this project during the funding period. Students have been trained in molecular biology (cloning, mutagenesis, protein overexpression), enzymology (radioassays, kinetics), and computational biophyics (molecular dynamics) approaches.

Scientific outreach activities have included after school science clubs for at-risk middle school students, led by first year undergraduates taking a seminar course in the history of women in science. The middle school students participated in activities that included quantitative components (the logrithmic nature of the pH scale) and fun applications of core science concepts (the acidity and basicity of household liquids, tested using cabbage juice pH indicator). Middle school students became familiar with the science topics even before their classmates, so could be content experts, while undergraduates gained fluency in explaining key concepts they would use in college science courses.
